DOC.HEAD: New Government Wins Confidence Vote
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh's minority government passed its first test of support Thursday, winning a vote of confidence in Parliament as expected. A chorus of ``Yes!'' arose when the vote was called and Speaker Rabi Ray of Singh's People's Party declared the motion carried. The Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi abstained. Singh, who led a broad coalition in the November elections, presented the confidence motion. He had pledges of support from several parties that would have given him more half the votes if a roll- call vote had been necessary. He took office Dec. 2, ending Gandhi's five-year tenure as prime minister, and named his Cabinet three days later. Under a deadline set by President Ramaswamy Venkataraman, he had until Jan. 1 to obtain approval from the legislators. Shortly before the vote was taken, Singh told Parliament his government showed India could turn from personalities to issues in choosing a leader. ``The delicate balance of political forces may turn out to be the most glorious occasion for our democracy,'' said the new prime minister, whose victory ended a hold on power by the Congress Party that extended back through Gandhi's mother, Indira, to his grandfather, Jawaharlal Nehru. It is only the second time since independence from Britain in 1947 that the Congress Party has not controlled the government. This also was the first time a prime minister or his party had initiated a confidence motion. The constitution does not require a confidence vote for a new government, but neither does it prohibit one. President Venkataraman felt a vote was the best way to determine whether Singh's government could function. In the elections, Gandhi's Congress Party won 193 of the 525 seats in the lower house of Parliament, making it the largest single party. The People's Party won 137 seats and its partners in the National Front alliance won three. Venkataraman asked Singh, 58, to form a government after he had obtained pledges of support from a Hindu nationalist party, with 86 seats, and a leftist alliance with 52.
